sentences.text: Chrome Version       : 6.0.401.1

I've been trying to test out webgl, but I can't seem to make it work on
Fedora at all.
My test page has been

http://www.nitobi.com/yohei/cube_defense_alpha/ , but I've also tried
pretty much everything on the first page of google hits for "webgl test".
Please note: I have tried this on clean installs (fully updated) of:
Fedora 12 (i386), Fedora 13 (i386 and x86_64).

The bug appears to be
exactly the same.

When I attempt to load a webgl page, the page pops up a
error notice that says:
"No WebGL Context found"

I get this error with --enable-gl, but on the advice of kbr (on #chromium),
I tried launching chromium-browser with --enable-webgl --in-process-webgl
to get additional debugging.

When I launch chromium-browser with --enable-webgl --in-process-webgl, I
see this on the console:

GraphicsContext3D: error opening libGL.so.1: libGL.so.1: cannot open shared
object file: Permission denied

I've done builds as both shared and static, it does not seem to affect thus
bug in any way.
On Fedora 12, mesa-libGL-7.7-4.fc12 is installed.
On Fedora 13, mesa-libGL-7.8.1-6.fc13 is installed.
None of the systems contain any binary-only crap (e.g.
nvidia).

There are
no selinux denials or alerts triggered.

To confirm that dlopening libGL.so.1 works on Fedora, I wrote a very very
trivial test program which mirrors what chromium appears to be doing in 
third_party/WebKit/WebKit/chromium/src/WebGraphicsContext3DDefaultImpl.cpp,
which is where that error message is coming from.
This test program is attached as dlopen-libGL-test.cpp.
When run on Fedora (12 & 13), this is the output:

[spot@pterodactyl ~]$ g++ -o dlopen-libGL-test dlopen-libGL-test.cpp -ldl
[spot@pterodactyl ~]$ .
/dlopen-libGL-test
Was able to dlopen libGL.so.1
(This is the expected output.)

Now, grepping through the source code, I count five places where it appears
to dlopen libGL.so.1:
* app/gfx/gl/gl_context_linux.cc
* chrome/gpu/gpu_main.cc
* media/tools/player_x11/gl_video_renderer.cc
* third_party/mesa/MesaLib/src/glx/x11/dri_common.c
* third_party/WebKit/WebKit/chromium/src/WebGraphicsContext3DDefaultImpl.cpp

The code in app/gfx/gl/gl_context_linux.cc doesn't seem to ever bother
running dlclose(), but I concede that it could be buried somewhere else.

The code in chrome/gpu/gpu_main.cc doesn't check for success there (which
it should, and output dlerror() if it fails).
Also, I don't see a dlclose()
here.

The code in media/tools/player_x11/gl_video_renderer.cc checks for success,
but doesn't output dlerror() on failure, instead, it does:
LOG(ERROR) << "Could not find libGL.so.1";
And again, no dlclose() here.

The code in third_party/mesa/MesaLib/src/glx/x11/dri_common.c does proper
error checking, with debugging that includes dlerror(), and a dlclose(),
but as I don't see that error, I can only assume that this code path is
either not being triggered or that it is properly dlopening libGL.so.1 here.
And lastly, the code which causes the error message,

third_party/WebKit/WebKit/chromium/src/WebGraphicsContext3DDefaultImpl.cpp
has proper error checking, with debugging that includes dlerror(), and a
dlclose (but only if the dlsym() calls fail).

I cede that dlclose() doesn't seem to be necessary for a successful
dlopen(), or even for repetitive dlopen() calls.

I'm not sure why chromium
needs to dlopen(libGL.so.1) five times, but I also admit to not being an
expert on dynamic loading.
(No comment was entered for this change.)

I added printfs to all of the codepaths where dlopen(libGL.so.1) is called (for
success and failure), and none of them trigger except for the one in
third_party/WebKit/WebKit/chromium/src/WebGraphicsContext3DDefaultImpl.cpp.

It seems
that as least as far as webgl is concerned, that's the only one that matters.
This is also the exact thing for me on Fedora 13
FWIW, I've never had webgl work for my on my (Ubuntu, Linux) laptop.

I figured it 
wasn't yet implemented so I haven't thought about it too hard.
It seems you've reduced the problem to that dlopen() failing:

GraphicsContext3D: error opening libGL.so.1: libGL.so.1: cannot open shared
object file: Permission denied

The error is quite curious -- it sounds like it's successfully found some file, but 
then is unable to open that file.

Perhaps you could try strace and see what file 
it's attempting to open.
BTW, the reason for all of these dlopening hijinks is an ugly workaround.

Really 
we'd just dynamically link against libGL like any other app.

// Some versions of NVIDIA's GL libGL.so include a broken version of
  // dlopen/dlsym, and so linking it into chrome breaks it.

So we dynamically
  // load it, and use glew to dynamically resolve symbols.
// See http://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?

id=16800
(Start with comment #38 there.)
It would be interesting to see what error gets thrown on Ubuntu, if any.
Error that is thrown on Kubuntu 9.10 (5.0.343.0 (40484) Ubuntu):

GraphicsContext3D: error opening libGL.so.1: libGL.so.1: cannot open shared object 
file: Permission denied
But if I run chromium with sudo, then it prints:
No protocol specified
GraphicsContext3D: error opening X display
Well, at least that much is consistent.
dlopen should not require sudo, as my test case code (attached to this ticket) specifies.
First, --in-process-webgl is not recommended and will not be supported forever.

Best to do your testing with 
just --enable-webgl.

Second, perhaps there is something wrong or missing in the code which disables the security sandbox when --
in-process-webgl is specified, which would lead to permission errors attempting to open libGL.so.1.
Well, for what it is worth, I don't get any error logging to the console without
--in-process-webgl, but webgl doesn't work (and the websites fail with the same error).
The logic about the security sandbox not being completely disabled with

--in-process-webgl makes sense, but if so, it just means that I'm back to square 1 on
trying to debug this. I would appreciate any additional suggestions or tips.
I think we should change some of the DLOGs to LOGs in src/app/gfx/gl/gl_context_linux.cc .
Is it possible for you to build Chromium?
Getting set up to build isn't difficult.

It would make it easier to figure 
out what's going on.
Umm, yes.

All of this testing has been done on builds of Chromium that I build
myself.
I'm the packager for the "semi-official" version of the Fedora chromium RPMS.
I can apply any suggested patches or make any changes that you need for debugging.

Could you change all the DLOGs to LOGs in src/app/gfx/gl/gl_context_linux.cc and see whether you get any 
errors reported around creation of the OpenGL context?
First test results (Fedora 12, i686, running in VM):

[5917:5917:613663675599:ERROR:app/gfx/gl/gl_context_linux.cc(277)] glXChooseFBConfig
failed.

I don't have time to do anything more today, but I will test on my actual Fedora 13
x86_64 system tomorrow.
Thanks for this output.
Could you post or attach the output of glxinfo tomorrow?
Rebuilt for Fedora 13, x86_64.
Error message is essentially identical.

[29082:29082:235691348750:ERROR:app/gfx/gl/gl_context_linux.cc(277)]
glXChooseFBConfig failed.
glxinfo attached.
The Intel graphics chip is a red flag.
glxinfo claims pbuffer support but I suspect it isn't really there.
It turns out glxinfo doesn't provide all of the desired information.

Is there any way you can check out the Mesa 
3D sources (see http://www.mesa3d.org/repository.html ) , cd to progs/xdemos and make and run pbinfo?
Also, a pixmap based initialization path was just added within the last couple of days.

If it isn't already in your 
app/gfx/gl/gl_context_linux.cc , could you sync to top of tree, rebuild, modify the DLOGs again and see what the 
results are after the glXChooseFBConfig fails?
Attached is the output from pbinfo on my Fedora 13 x86_64 system.
With 6.0.412.0 (svn47812) on my Fedora 13 x86_64 laptop, this is the result:
[spot@pterodactyl ~]$ chromium-browser --enable-webgl

[6520:6520:8456886147:ERROR:app/gfx/gl/gl_context_linux.cc(305)] glXChooseFBConfig
failed.

[6520:6520:8456939352:ERROR:app/gfx/gl/gl_context_linux.cc(305)] glXChooseFBConfig
failed.

WebGL enabled test pages don't throw the "No WebGL Context found" error anymore, but
they're definitely not working at all.
Could you apply the attached patch to gl_context_linux.cc and see whether it improves the behavior?
Patch applied, does not change behavior.
Webgl apps still do not run, console output is:
[spot@pterodactyl ~]$ chromium-browser --enable-webgl

[3988:3988:3026727240:ERROR:app/gfx/gl/gl_context_linux.cc(301)] glXChooseFBConfig
failed.

[3988:3988:3026817140:ERROR:app/gfx/gl/gl_context_linux.cc(301)] glXChooseFBConfig
failed.
The following revision refers to this bug:
http://src.chromium.org/viewvc/chrome?
view=rev&revision=48045
M http://src.chromium.org/viewvc/chrome/trunk/src/app/gfx/gl/gl_context_linux.cc?

Changed DLOG to LOG in gl_context_linux.cc to get informative error
messages even in release builds when WebGL initialization fails.
TEST=none
Review URL: http://codereview.chromium.org/2110012
Okay, here's what I've discovered.

I started trying to simplify this issue, and I found that both glxpbdemo and pbdemo
(from mesa/progs/xdemos) were both crashing with the same error.

Digging further, I
found that the issue had been opened upstream, and a patch written:
https://bugs.freedesktop.org/show_bug.cgi?

Sure enough, with that patch applied, glxpbdemo and pbdemo started working properly
and chromium stopped throwing that error (or any error).

Unfortunately, webgl apps still aren't working for me, nothing gets drawn on the
screen.
I tried going to

https://cvs.khronos.org/svn/repos/registry/trunk/public/webgl/sdk/tests/webgl-conformance-tests.html
, and some of those tests seem to succeed, but the browser tab eventually "oh
snap!"'
s.
I would like to help debugging this, please advise.
Following up on my own query, I've finally found some webgl demos that work!
From: http://www.khronos.org/webgl/wiki/Demo_Repository

shiny-teapot did not work (teapot per vertex and teapot per pixel draw a black box,
but nothing shows up in them).

Many Planets Deep worked on the second try (first try was our old friend "no WebGL
context found")
Every other demo WORKED!
http://www.teslacore.it/projects/webgl/demoLife/ also works.

Chocolux claims to work, but i don't think it is rendering properly, as it looks like
a flat brown box (although, the fps is going up and down as if it is running).
http://www.satine.org/research/webkit/webgl/chocolux.html
I'm glad that things are beginning to work on your distribution.
It sounds like the remaining issues may be graphics driver bugs.

If you can dig deeper into the failures of some of 
the demos, starting with the simpler ones, we can try to figure out whether there are workarounds possible in the 
WebGL implementation.
I would like to close this bug;
do you have any concerns about my doing so?
No issue with closing this bug, as it is not a chromium issue.

I would however appreciate any documentation or advice on how to dig deeper into the
failures of the demos, along with any explicit suggestions on which demos are
"simpler ones".
The demos in the demo repository are simple ones to start debugging.

http://www.khronos.org/webgl/wiki/Demo_Repository has instructions on how to check out the demos on 
your local machine.

Note that running these within Chromium off your local disk requires --allow-file-access-
from-files on the command line (not recommended for general browsing however).
Open the JavaScript error console and look for anything printed there.

Also look at 
http://khronos.org/webgl/wiki/Debugging for how to see any OpenGL errors generated by the application.
Closing as WontFix as the Chromium code appears to be working as intended.

title: webgl does not work on Fedora
